Lesson 3: Expense Categories

Image by rawpixel.com under Freepik

Let’s deepen our understanding of costs by looking at general expense categories first. There is no perfect standard for how child care business costs are categorized, but these general categories can give us an idea of what to expect.

Instructions: In the list below, identify how expensive program costs are as a percentage of an annual budget. Using the dropdowns select the most expensive, second most expensive, third most expensive, and least expensive for each statement. Select the Check Answers button to check your answers.


How Expensive General Expense Category Feedback
Most Expensive Staffing Costs (salary and benefits for administrative, child care, and other program staff) The most expensive category of costs in child care is staffing, accounting for 60-80% of annual costs. Child care is extremely labor intensive and costs can go up depending on the educator’s qualifications and benefits like health care, retirement, etc.
Second Most Expensive Office and Administration (accounting, legal, advertising and operating consultants and fees, internet, phone) Office and Administration costs fluctuate between 5-15% and can vary depending on program type and location.
Third Most Expensive Occupancy (rent/mortgage, maintenance, repairs) Occupancy can vary greatly depending on program type and location also.
Least Expensive Supplies (food services and supplies, educational supplies, health/medical supplies) Supplies usually take the smallest portion of the budget and are largely dependent on the services offered, like meals and snacks, and dependent on enrollment and age of children served.

Specific Expense Categories and Cost Type

Now let’s get more detailed about what each general expense category may include. The Expense Categories handout includes this information and can be referenced as needed.

Instructions: Select the left and right arrow to navigate through the slideshow on what general expense categories may include.

  • Fixed Expenses

    Fringe Benefits, Occupancy, and Insurance

  • Fringe Benefits

    Includes the cost of any benefits provided for program staff applicable to the program including but not limited to: social security insurance (FICA), unemployment insurance, retirement contributions, health insurance, workers compensation, retirement contributions, and reduced tuition for employee children. Even if the business increases its revenue, fringe benefits won’t change.

  • Occupancy

    Includes space rental or mortgage and utilities. Regardless of enrollment or revenue, these costs remain the same.

  • Insurance

    Includes liability and accident insurance. Premiums for business-related insurances recur in regular intervals and amounts.

  • Variable Expenses

    Personnel, Travel, Printing/Reproduction, and Other Expenses

  • Personnel

    While an owner’s salary is fixed, other personnel costs will likely be variable unless it is a very small program, like a family child care without additional staff or just one assistant and/or all staff are on salaries that do not change based on hours worked. Wages paid hourly will fluctuate depending on how much time is spent on the job.

  • Travel

    Includes staff travel for program related activities such as field trips or professional development sponsored or required by the program and school field trips. Some activities may or may not be done based on overall budget and enrollment could easily impact this cost.

  • Printing/Reproduction

    Includes flyers, brochures, and reproduction of materials. The needs of the business, including enrollment, will determine what and how much gets printed/reproduced.

  • Other Expenses

    Includes any other expense, such as criminal history/child abuse clearance. By nature, these costs don’t fall neatly into other categories and therefore are variable.

  • Either Fixed or Variable Cost

    Supplies, Equipment, Consultants, Advertising/Promotion, Staff Training, and Transportation

  • Supplies

    Includes expenses for all supplies needed to operate, including but not limited to the following categories: Educational (classroom curriculum, materials for arts projects, science experiments, etc.), Administrative/Office (pens and paper, filing cabinets in the program director’s office), Cleaning and Health (cleaning and sanitation supplies, health/medical supplies), and Food (snacks, ingredients for in-house meal preparation, consumable products and related serving supplies). Supply costs can be fixed or variable. If enrollment changes, the amount and thus the cost of food will change. Things like classroom curriculum and office supplies remain consistent regardless of enrollment.

  • Equipment

    Includes purchased or rented equipment for program operation including any associated maintenance and repair costs. Equipment (as opposed to supplies) are high cost items valued over $500, for example computers or playgrounds. While the price for equipment will remain consistent, maintenance and repair costs can vary, meaning it can fall into fixed or variable costs.

  • Consultants

    Includes CPA, legal, and advertising consultants. While you may plan for basic accounting expenses to help with taxes, you may need to hire consultants throughout the year that you never anticipated for legal advice or improving enrollment.

  • Advertising/Promotion

    Includes advertising and marketing to recruit families and/or hire for new positions. Some advertising costs will largely stay the same. For example, website hosting and social media management, if applicable, will usually be charged as recurring costs at the same rates. However, a drop in enrollment might require more investment in advertising costs.

  • Staff Training

    Includes the costs of instructional materials, equipment, and time for formal training in addition to speaker fees. New employees hired outside of timelines for routine staff training may incur additional fees to be trained.

  • Transportation

    If applicable, includes transportation for children to or from the program. If the fee for transportation is per student, the total cost will fluctuate with enrollment. If there is a flat fee for a bus that will hold up to all students, the total cost will not change unless enrollment changes significantly.

Instructions: Are the following expense categories variable or fixed? In the list below, identify which are variable and which are fixed. Using the dropdowns select variable or fixed for each expense category. Select the Check Answers button to check your answers.


Expense Expense Category Feedback
Fixed Fringe Benefits Remains consistent regardless of enrollment.
Variable Personnel Variable because it usually fluctuates depending on enrollments.
Variable Supplies Variable because it usually fluctuates depending on enrollments.
Variable Printing Variable because it usually fluctuates depending on enrollments.
Fixed Occupancy Remains consistent regardless of enrollment.
